prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Dust continuum observation at band 6 lower for source gp 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We observe dust continuum emissions and determine flux densities at band 6 with LO1 of 231 GHz. The determined flux density is used to make a Spectral Energy Distribution for an estimation of the central protostellar mass.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to survey dust continuum emissions at band 6 with LO1 of 231 GHz to make a Spectral Energy Distribution (SED) for an estimation of the central protostellar mass. Target sources are G000.54-00.85 SE, G002.53+00.19, G006.79-00.25, and G008.83-00.02.
The spatial angular resolution is set to 0.186 arcsec achieved in the most extended configuration, which is the finest at this band, to resolve possibly central areas within the disk (~0.3-0.5 arcsec). Spectral type is set to "Single Continuum" mode in order to achieve the best sensitivity with a bandwidth of 7.5 GHz for the best signal to noise ratio (SNR). Observational frequencies are set up to obtain a possibly wide band data combined with continuum data at other frequency band.
Required sensitivities are estimated on the basis of predicted flux densities with the following parameters: the gas volume density of 10^8 cm^-3 and the dust temperature of 200 K which is a suitable environment to excite the CH3OH maser, the column density of ~10^24 cm^-2, the gas-to-dust ratio of 100, the opacity index of 1.0 at the minimum case, and the disk size represented by the major axis on the maser ellipse in each source. Each predicted flux density is referred to Table 1 in the Scientific justification. As a result, we set the desired sensitivity per pointing of 0.2 mJy achieving SNR of ~80 at least, without an extension of observing time.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Dust continuum observation at band 6 upper for source gp 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We observe dust continuum emissions and determine flux densities at band 6 with LO1 of 255 GHz. The determined flux density is used to make a Spectral Energy Distribution for an estimation of the central protostellar mass.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to survey dust continuum emissions at band 6 with LO1 of 255 GHz to make a Spectral Energy Distribution (SED) for an estimation of the central protostellar mass. Target sources are G000.54-00.85 SE, G002.53+00.19, G006.79-00.25, and G008.83-00.02.
The spatial angular resolution is set to 0.168 arcsec achieved in the most extended configuration, which is the finest at this band, to resolve possibly central areas within the disk (~0.3-0.5 arcsec). Spectral type is set to "Single Continuum" mode in order to achieve the best sensitivity with a bandwidth of 7.5 GHz for the best signal to noise ratio (SNR). Observational frequencies are set up to obtain a possibly wide band data combined with continuum data at other frequency band.
Required sensitivities are estimated on the basis of predicted flux densities with the following parameters: the gas volume density of 10^8 cm^-3 and the dust temperature of 200 K which is a suitable environment to excite the CH3OH maser, the column density of ~10^24 cm^-2, the gas-to-dust ratio of 100, the opacity index of 1.0 at the minimum case, and the disk size represented by the major axis on the maser ellipse in each source. Each predicted flux density is referred to Table 1 in the Scientific justification. As a result, we set the desired sensitivity per pointing of 0.2 mJy achieving SNR of ~140 at least, without an extension of observing time.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Dust continuum and CH3CN line observations at band 7 for source gp 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
We observe dust continuum emissions and determine flux densities at band 7 with LO1 of 344 GHz. The determined flux density is used to make a Spectral Energy Distribution for an estimation of the central protostellar mass.
We also observe CH3CN molecular line emissions at J=19-18 with K of 0-6 transitions.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to survey dust continuum emissions at band 7 with LO1 of 344 GHz to make a Spectral Energy Distribution (SED) for an estimation of the central protostellar mass. Also we observe CH3CN molecular line emissions to reveal disk structures and kinematics around a high-mass protostar. Target sources are G000.54-00.85 SE, G002.53+00.19, G006.79-00.25, and G008.83-00.02.
The spatial angular resolution is set to 0.118 arcsec achieved in the most extended configuration, which is the finest at this band, to resolve possibly central areas within the disk (~0.3-0.5 arcsec). Spectral type is set to "Spectral Line" mode and at Baseband-1 we set the center frequency of 349.21234 GHz corresponding to the rest frequency of CH3CN J=19-18 at K-transitions of 6. This center frequency covers all of target CH3CN line emissions of K-transitions 0-6 with the bandwidth of 937.5 MHz. In this sepctral set-up, the spectral resolution of ~0.4 km/s, which is enough to resolve the line FWHM of ~3.0 km/s predicted with the central mass and the st extended configuration, which is the finest at this band, to resolve possibly central areas within the disk (~0.3-0.5 arcsec). Spectral type is set to "Spectral Line" mode and at Baseband-1 we set the center frequency of 349.21234 GHz corresponding to the rest frequency of CH3CN J=19-18 at K-transitions of 6. This center frequency covers all of target CH3CN line emissions of K-transitions 0-6 with the bandwidth of 937.5 MHz. In this sepctral set-up, the spectral resolution of ~0.4 km/s is achieved, which is enough to resolve the line FWHM of ~3.0 km/s predicted with the central mass and the size of the disk inferred from the bolometric luminosity and size of the disk based on the bolometric luminosity and the size of the maser ellipse, respectively. Also, we set other Baseband (2-4) to the widest bandwidth of 2.0 GHz each in order to achieve the best sensitivity for continuum data, providing a net bandwidth of ~6.5 GHz. Observational frequencies are set up to obtain a possibly wide band data combined with continuum data at other frequency band.
Required sensitivities for the CH3CN line detections are estimated on the basis of predicted brightness temperatures calculated using the non-LTE radiative transfer code (RADEX: Van der Tak et al. 2007, A&A, 468, 627) with the following parameters: the kinetic temperature of 100 K, the abundance ratio of CH3CN of 10^-9 at the minimum case, the gas volume density of 10^8 cm^-3 which is the suitable environment to excite the CH3OH maser, and the column density of ~10^24 cm^-2. Each predicted brightness temperature is referred to Table 1 in the Scientific justification. As a result, we set the desired sensitivity per pointing of 9.4 K achieving SNR higher than 5 in all of target sources, except for the CH3CN line of K-transitin 6 in G008.83-00.02 (SNR ~4). Same sensitivity set-up provides us SNR of ~650 for the continuum observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Dust continuum observation at band 6 lower for source gp 2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We observe dust continuum emissions and determine flux densities at band 6 with LO1 of 231 GHz. The determined flux density is used to make a Spectral Energy Distribution for an estimation of the central protostellar mass.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to survey dust continuum emissions at band 6 with LO1 of 231 GHz to make a Spectral Energy Distribution (SED) for an estimation of the central protostellar mass. A target source is G025.82-00.17.
The spatial angular resolution is set to 0.172 arcsec achieved in the most extended configuration, which is the finest at this band, to resolve possibly central areas within the disk (~0.45 arcsec). Spectral type is set to "Single Continuum" mode in order to achieve the best sensitivity with a bandwidth of 7.5 GHz for the best signal to noise ratio (SNR). Observational frequencies are set up to obtain a possibly wide band data combined with continuum data at other frequency band.
Required sensitivities are estimated on the basis of predicted flux densities with the following parameters: the gas volume density of 10^8 cm^-3 and the dust temperature of 200 K which is a suitable environment to excite the CH3OH maser, the column density of ~10^24 cm^-2, the gas-to-dust ratio of 100, the opacity index of 1.0 at the minimum case, and the disk size represented by the major axis on the maser ellipse in each source. The predicted flux density is referred to Table 1 in the Scientific justification. As a result, we set the desired sensitivity per pointing of 0.1 mJy achieving SNR of ~710, without an extension of observing time.

We propose to survey dust continuum emissions at band 6 with LO1 of 255 GHz to make a Spectral Energy Distribution (SED) for an estimation of the central protostellar mass. A target source is G025.82-00.17.
The spatial angular resolution is set to 0.168 arcsec achieved in the most extended configuration, which is the finest at this band, to resolve possibly central areas within the disk (~0.45 arcsec). Spectral type is set to "Single Continuum" mode in order to achieve the best sensitivity with a bandwidth of 7.5 GHz for the best signal to noise ratio (SNR). Observational frequencies are set up to obtain a possibly wide band data combined with continuum data at other frequency band.
Required sensitivities are estimated on the basis of predicted flux densities with the following parameters: the gas volume density of 10^8 cm^-3 and the dust temperature of 200 K which is a suitable environment to excite the CH3OH maser, the column density of ~10^24 cm^-2, the gas-to-dust ratio of 100, the opacity index of 1.0 at the minimum case, and the disk size represented by the major axis on the maser ellipse in each source. The predicted flux density is referred to Table 1 in the Scientific justification. As a result, we set the desired sensitivity per pointing of 0.1 mJy achieving SNR of ~1270, without an extension of observing time.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Dust continuum and CH3CN line observations at band 7 for source gp 2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
We observe dust continuum emissions and determine flux densities at band 7 with LO1 of 344 GHz. The determined flux density is used to make a Spectral Energy Distribution for an estimation of the central protostellar mass.
We also observe CH3CN molecular line emissions at J=19-18 with K of 0-6 transitions.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to survey dust continuum emissions at band 7 with LO1 of 344 GHz to make a Spectral Energy Distribution (SED) for an estimation of the central protostellar mass. Also we observe CH3CN molecular line emissions to reveal disk structures and kinematics around a high-mass protostar. A target source is G025.82-00.17
The spatial angular resolution is set to 0.118 arcsec achieved in the most extended configuration, which is the finest at this band, to resolve possibly central areas within the disk (~0.45 arcsec). Spectral type is set to "Spectral Line" mode and at Baseband-1 we set the center frequency of 349.21234 GHz corresponding to the rest frequency of CH3CN J=19-18 at K-transitions of 6. This center frequency covers all of target CH3CN line emissions of K-transitions 0-6 with the bandwidth of 937.5 MHz. In this sepctral set-up, the spectral resolution of ~0.4 km/s is achieved, which is enough to resolve the line FWHM of ~3.0 km/s predicted with the central mass and the size of the disk inferred from the bolometric luminosity and the size of the maser ellipse, respectively. Also, we set other Baseband (2-4) to the widest bandwidth of 2.0 GHz each in order to achieve the best sensitivity for continuum data, providing a net bandwidth of ~6.5 GHz. Observational frequencies are set up to obtain a possibly wide band data combined with continuum data at other frequency band.
Required sensitivities for the CH3CN line detections are estimated on the basis of predicted brightness temperatures calculated using the non-LTE radiative transfer code (RADEX: Van der Tak et al. 2007, A&A, 468, 627) with the following parameters: the kinetic temperature of 100 K, the abundance ratio of CH3CN of 10^-9 at the minimum case, the gas volume density of 10^8 cm^-3 which is the suitable environment to excite the CH3OH maser, and the column density of ~10^24 cm^-2. The predicted brightness temperature is referred to Table 1 in the Scientific justification. As a result, we set the desired sensitivity per pointing of 5.0 K achieving SNR higher than 11 in all transitions, without an extension of observing time.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose high-spatial-resolution imaging survey of dust continuum and CH3CN line emissions associated with 6.7 GHz CH3OH maser sources showing elliptical morphology, which are potential candidates of accretion disk/molecular torus around a high-mass protostar. By comparing distribution of dust and molecular line emissions traced by using ALMA with the maser distributions already obtained with East-Asian VLBI Network (EAVN), we will be able to test whether the ellipitical structures traced by CH3OH masers are disks around protostars. Also, the continuum peak position determined by ALMA will provide an important reference point to measure relative proper motions of the masers, which will allow us to kinematically test the disk possibility of CH3OH masers when combined with our on-going proper-motion survey of CH3OH masers using EAVN.
